_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at our facility:

Keyera is committed to the safety of its workers, the public, and the environment. Its accidental release policy is an integrated approach, involving employee participation, management practices, written procedures, and training. Keyera has developed a comprehensive propane accident prevention program considering all aspects of process operation and maintenance. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to notify the City of Vancouver

Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency. We also maintain incipient stage fire fighting equipment on site. Additionally the facility has been equipped with fire suppression cannon nozzles along the facility perimeter. This facility complies with NFPA-58 requirements for LP-Gas storage, and it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. The facility came online new in 2011 and is annually inspected for compliance by the City of Vancouver. 

A description of our facility and the regulated substances handled: 

This facility is a bulk terminal storing LPG for resale to retail propane dealers. The facility consists of two 80,000-gallon tanks holding approximately 285,600 pounds each of liquid propane. There is also the capacity for sixteen 33,000-gallon rail cars onsite and capacity for another six 33,000-gallon rail cars adjacent to the facility on leased property. There are both manual and automatic emergency shutdown systems on all LPG equipment at the site.

The worst-case and alternative release scenarios:

Our worst-case scenario is failure of both of the 80,000-gallon storage tanks or the connecting piping when each of the storage tanks are filled to the greatest amount allowed (88% at 60F), resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. It assumes all the propane is released and ignited. No passive mitigation system is considered. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite to 0.7 miles,

and public receptors (one residence, one prison, and the Port of Vancouver Industrial Park) are within the distance to the endpoint. Keyera has multiple safeguards in place which make this scenario very unlikely. Our alternative release scenario involves a propane release from a multi-port 2.5 inch relief valve over a 5-minute period at a rate of 819 pounds per minute. An excess flow check valve is the active mitigation system considered in this scenario. A total of 6,890 pounds of propane is ignited, resulting is a vapor cloud explosion. This would generate a pressure wave with a minimum 1 psi overpressure extending 0.1 miles. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite. The only public receptors within the distance to the endpoint is the industrial park. 

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. The propane system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA-58 and state law.

Five-year accident history:

The terminal facility is new in February 2011. There has not been an accident involving propane that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in-place. 

The emergency response program:

In the event of an emergency involving our propane system, it is our policy to notify the City of Vancouver Fire Department and request that they help respond to the emergency. Keyera also has trained employees in incipient stage fire fighting. We have coordinated our response plans with the fire department; members of the fire department have been provided the opportunity to visit our facility and inspect our propane storage system.

Planned changes to improve safety:
